15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"US again shatters record number of daily new COVID-19 cases with 97,080 — as case numbers continue to grow much faster than testing, despite Trump's claims","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/daily-covid-cases-case-numbers-rise-faster-testing-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9cd5f569331a0011bc68bf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"coronavirus testing florida\" height=\"2079\" width=\"2772\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A medical professional administers a COVID-19 test at a drive-thru testing site in Orlando, Florida on Thursday.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Joe Burbank/Orlando Sentinel/Tribune News Service via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The US hit a record number of daily coronavirus cases with 97,080 on Friday, as case numbers continue to grow much faster than testing, according to data from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/COVID19Tracking/status/1322315688116019200\">The COVID Tracking Project</a>.</li>\n<li>This contradicts President Donald Trump, who has said repeatedly in recent weeks that the number of coronavirus cases is growing due to increased testing.</li>\n<li>Admiral Brett Giroir, the Trump administration's testing czar, has also said the case surge is \"not just a function of testing.\"</li>\n<li>The COVID Tracking Project also counted nearly 1.4 million tests that same day, with nearly 47,000 people hospitalized and a daily death count of 933.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The US hit a record number of new daily coronavirus cases with 97,080 on Friday, as case numbers continue to grow much faster than testing, according to data from <a href=\"https://twitter.com/COVID19Tracking/status/1322315688116019200\">The COVID Tracking Project</a>.</p><p>The Project counted nearly 1.4 million tests that same day, with nearly 47,000 people hospitalized for COVID-19 and a daily death count of 933.</p><p>The data also showed that case numbers are rising much more sharply than the number of tests being administered, which The Project called \"an indication of uncontrolled spread\" of the virus.</p><p>This contradicts President Donald Trump, who has said repeatedly in recent weeks that the number of coronavirus cases is growing due to increased testing.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;The COVID Tracking Project  (@COVID19Tracking) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1322321566454018049?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 30, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>\"Cases up because we TEST, TEST, TEST,\" Trump said <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1320708386476990464\">Monday on Twitter</a>. He repeated the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1322150249255895042\">claim again in a tweet</a> today as the US broke its daily case record.</p><p>But Admiral Brett Giroir, the Trump administration's testing czar, said the data show testing is not the reason for the case surge in an interview on <a href=\"https://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/coronavirus/coronavirus-testing-czar-rise-in-hospitalizations-deaths-proof-of-surge-in-cases/2351790/\">NBC's Today's Show</a> earlier this week.</p><p>\"It's not just a function of testing,\" he said. \"We do assess that the cases are actually going up, they're real, because hospitalizations and deaths are starting to go up.\"</p><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9cd5f569331a0011bc68bf?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3c1aae8ba18f83661400d289459a1db2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn7@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-07-523_3d50c54c66bd9caa.webp","destWidth":2772,"destHeight":2079,"sourceBytes":236798,"destBytes":236798,"author":"kvlamis@businessinsider.com (Kelsey Vlamis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9cd5f569331a0011bc68bf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn7@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-07-523_3d50c54c66bd9caa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-995_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B9tjPuhUMvU:LHP8eBLXxGA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn9@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-37-471_ee4b669f38ebbc20.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B9tjPuhUMvU:LHP8eBLXxGA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn87@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-32-222_3396ec79f8113c44.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-32-089_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B9tjPuhUMvU:LHP8eBLXxGA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn40@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-37-810_d68d8c4298e36ce9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/B9tjPuhUMvU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn91@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-29-980_c0d2e8b824a1cd23.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167079},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"Pinterest is booming as online shopping surges and Americans seek a soothing escape from reality","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pinterest-3rd-quarter-blowout-result-of-ecommerce-surge-escapism-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c604469331a0011bc66e3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ben silbermann pinterest\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Pinterest founders Ben Silbermann, left, and Evan Sharp.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Richard Drew/AP Photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Pinterest reported blow-out third-quarter earnings this week, with revenue up 58% year-over-year.&#160;</li>\n<li>Its strong quarter was due to a combination of factors, most of which are related to the coronavirus pandemic: increased engagement during COVID lockdowns, a rise in online shopping, and people seeking an escape from a grim news cycle.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"At Pinterest, we continued to focus on what we can control: supporting all of our stakeholders in this unpredictable time,\" CEO Ben Silbermann and CFO Todd Morgenfeld wrote in a letter to shareholders. \"This included giving Pinners and brands a positive place to be online during a divisive election in the United States.\"</li>\n<li>Pinterest saw a 37% increase in monthly active users since last year, with strong growth among young users. The company also noted user growth after the release of iOS 14, when users were looking for home</li>\n<li>screen inspiration.&#160;</li>\n<li>Pinterest is unique among social media apps for its lack of news posts and internet trolls. Its strong quarter proves that the app is a pleasant, dependable distraction during a challenging time.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>If you open up Pinterest right now, you'll see pictures of people are wearing expertly applied makeup and well-tailored outfits, beautiful home decor, delicious-looking recipes, and travels to the American Southwest or the Amalfi Coast.</p><p>In the world depicted on Pinterest, employment is high, the election isn't a factor, and no one is wearing a mask, because there is no pandemic.&#160;</p><p>Throughout the last eight months, I have turned to Pinterest almost religiously as a brief escape from everyday life. The app serves as a virtual mood board and recommendation engine, and offers up an endless stream of content curated around both my current interests and those I haven't discovered yet. For me, it's a pleasant, dependable distraction.&#160;</p><p>It seems I'm not alone. After a decade of being something of an anti-social-network with a devoted following of hobbyists, Pinterest is surging.&#160;The company posted <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/28/pinterest-stock-soars-more-than-10percent-revenue-up-49percent.html\">blow-out third-quarter earnings</a> this week, reporting $443 million in revenue, up 58% year over year. The app is now boasting 442 million users worldwide, a 37% growth in monthly active users since last year. Pinterest's strong quarter sent its stock <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/29/pinterest-more-than-delivered-the-goods-in-q3-on-back-of-ad-rebound.html\">soaring 27%</a> on Wednesday.&#160;</p><p>Pinterest isn't shying away from its position as a positive place to hang out in an otherwise bleak landscape.</p><p>\"In Q3, the world was still dealing with the economic and health challenges brought on by COVID-19. Nobody knows exactly how all of this will play out,\" CEO Ben Silbermann and CFO Todd Morgenfeld wrote in a letter to shareholders.</p><p>\"But at Pinterest, we continued to focus on what we can control: supporting all of our stakeholders in this unpredictable time. This included giving Pinners and brands a positive place to be online during a divisive election in the United States,\" they wrote.</p><h2>High engagement during lockdowns</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9b322069331a0011bc6316?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Pinterest\" height=\"1998\" width=\"2664\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rich Polk/Getty Images for Pinterest</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Pinterest's strong quarter was fueled by a swell of new users on the platform, particularly those under 25, Silbermann and Morgenfeld noted in the shareholder letter.</p><p>Many of those <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-ios-14-widgets-home-screen-ideas-pinterest-downloads-2020-9\">young users flocked to Pinterest</a> after the release of iOS 14, Apple's latest smartphone operating system, which allows iPhone users to customize their home screens using widgets. The hunt for home screen inspiration led to millions of new users, Pinterest said.&#160;</p><p>\"We experienced a particular benefit of about 4 million global MAUs at the end of the quarter as younger users upgraded their iPhones to iOS 14 and used Pinterest for inspiration for customized background filters,\" Silbermann and Morgenfeld wrote.</p><p>Overall, app usage seems closely tied to the pandemic: The company said it saw higher engagement during coronavirus lockdowns — when those lockdowns lifted, Pinterest saw engagement decrease. Users who joined during the pandemic have been relying Pinterest to search for something specific, the company says, and have \"higher commercial intent\" — meaning, those users are looking to shop. Pinterest says that the number of users engaging with its built-in shopping platform is risen 85% since March.</p><p>Andrew Lipsman, a principal analyst at eMarketer, said following Pinterest's earnings that the company is a beneficiary of the rise in online shopping.</p><p>\"The company is especially well positioned for the moment, with users flocking to the site for inspiration amid new pandemic habits and also benefiting from the surge in ecommerce buying,\" Lipsman wrote.</p><p>Analysts at MKM Partners said that although it's still \"early days\" for shopping on Pinterest, growth will only continue, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/29/pinterest-more-than-delivered-the-goods-in-q3-on-back-of-ad-rebound.html\">according to CNBC</a>.&#160;</p><p>\"Catalog growth and integration with leading eCommerce ecosystem stakeholders such as Shopify is going to increase the importance of Pinterest in the overall shopping funnel,\" the firm wrote.</p><p>But there's more to Pinterest's growth than bored young people stuck inside or a global acceleration in online shopping: advertisers are looking for a more pleasant place to spend their money.</p><p>Pinterest has <a href=\"https://business.pinterest.com/content/it-pays-to-be-positive/\">billed itself</a> to advertisers as a smarter alternative to Facebook, Twitter, and other social media sites given its lack of news-related content and its reputation for having fewer internet trolls. This past summer, when civil rights organizations urged brands to stop advertising on Facebook over its hate-speech moderation and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/companies-no-longer-advertising-on-facebook-after-poor-speech-moderation-2020-6\">major companies like Starbucks, Unilever, and Verizon joined the boycott</a>, it seems to have paid off for Pinterest, at least in the near-term.&#160;</p><p>\"Spend from the group of advertisers boycotting social media accelerated in Q3, though it's not yet clear how sustainable this trend will be, particularly after the US presidential election cycle ends,\" Silbermann and Morgenfeld wrote in the shareholder letter.</p><p>Morgenfeld said during the company's earnings call though Pinterest isn't banking on the trend to continue, it believes \"the positivity of Pinterest is a long-term competitive advantage.\"</p><p>While there's no telling if Pinterest's welcoming and stress-free platform will continue to fuel it's growth in the fourth quarter and beyond, one thing remains true: for anyone overwhelmed by the news cycle or looking for a few minutes of escape, Pinterest remains one of the most relaxing places on the internet.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The American Medical Association hit back on Friday after President Donald Trump suggested doctors are inflating COVID-19 death counts for money, as cases continue to stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The American Medical Association hit back on Friday after President Donald Trump falsely suggested doctors are inflating COVID-19 death counts for money, as cases continue to climb across the country.</p><p>During a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/atrupar/status/1322244181037821954?s=20\">Michigan rally on Friday</a>, the president lamented the increase in coronavirus cases, blaming it on an increase in testing, a claim <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/daily-covid-cases-case-numbers-rise-faster-testing-2020-10\">his own testing czar has disputed</a>. He then said doctors are improperly citing COVID-19 as a cause of death in some cases for monetary gain.</p><p>\"You know, our doctors get more money if someone dies from COVID. You know that, right?\" Trump asked the crowd. He characterized US doctors on the frontlines of coronavirus as saying, \"When in doubt, choose COVID,\" for the cause of death.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Aaron Rupar  (@atrupar) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1322244181037821954?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 30, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>The AMA, the country's largest association of physicians, responded to the accusation in a strongly-worded <a href=\"https://www.ama-assn.org/press-center/ama-statements/ama-statement-ongoing-attacks-physicians-treating-covid-patients\">statement</a> that did not address the president by name. The statement said frontline healthcare workers have risked their lives to fight the virus \"because duty called and because of the sacred oath they took.\"</p><p>\"The suggestion that doctors — in the midst of a public health crisis — are overcounting COVID-19 patients or lying to line their pockets is a malicious, outrageous, and completely misguided charge,\" Susan Bailey, president of the AMA, said.</p><p>\"Rather than attacking us and lobbing baseless charges at physicians, our leaders should be following the science and urging adherence to the public health steps we know work — wearing a mask, washing hands, and practicing physical distancing,\" she added.</p><p>The statement also noted that coronavirus cases are currently at record-high numbers. According to The COVID Tracking Project, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/daily-covid-cases-case-numbers-rise-faster-testing-2020-10\">US daily case number broke records again on Friday</a> by surpassing 97,000 cases.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 05:08:13 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9ce74a69331a0011bc68c4?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"479883436e718ee3f1ece949d9bcd15b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn91@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-26-945_9ac9b8486bc216fb.webp","destWidth":1673,"destHeight":1255,"sourceBytes":82480,"destBytes":82480,"author":"kvlamis@businessinsider.com (Kelsey Vlamis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9ce7526f5b310011724a87?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn48@2020_3/2020/10/31/07-26-37-967_133832cad37bcfc3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-995_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=W7gA-UDnvU0:ceTNZbbhOmA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn9@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-36-044_31dbf1e79059fbdb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=W7gA-UDnvU0:ceTNZbbhOmA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn62@2020_5/2020/10/31/07-26-25-953_6c46d13edba3c50a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-32-089_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=W7gA-UDnvU0:ceTNZbbhOmA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn83@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-30-674_1354d94189576245.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/W7gA-UDnvU0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn47@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-34-790_05356cd3d828477c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167073},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"If Biden wins the 2020 presidential election, he may have suburban women to thank","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/insider-poll-biden-is-winning-over-suburban-women-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c632e6f5b3100117248d2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Women biden harris suburban supporters\" height=\"1800\" width=\"3600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Two women holding Biden/Harris lawns signs take a selfie at a rally with Democratic Senate candidates Rev. Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff on October 24, 2020, in Duluth, Georgia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Elijah Nouvelage/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Suburban women are critical for Joe Biden to win the election and they are learning toward the Democratic nominee in the lead up to November 3.&#160;</li>\n<li>According to recent Insider polling, Biden has a 7 percentage point lead over President Donald Trump among respondents from that voting bloc.</li>\n<li>Appearing to understand the importance of the suburban female vote, Trump tried to woo this demographic at recent rallies.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Suburban women may well be Democratic nominee Joe Biden's ticket to the White House and, with four days until the election, it appears that they prefer him to President Donald Trump.</p><p>Recent Insider polling showed that Biden is 7 percentage points ahead of Trump within that voting bloc.</p><p>The chart below shows the difference between the margin of support for Trump and Biden among the given subset of respondents and the overall margin of support among likely voters as a whole:&#160;</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on location and gender\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-m6Hmn\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/m6Hmn/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"604\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>According to recent polling from Insider and SurveyMonkey, suburban women tend to prefer Biden for president at higher rates than men. While men and women from rural and urban areas tended to vote similarly, a split is seen along gender lines in suburban areas that may define the outcome of this election cycle.&#160;</p><p>This breakdown comes from an aggregation of nine polls taken between August 8 and October 12. All told, the polls combined to 10,077 respondents, 8,623 of whom indicated they were registered to vote and 8,321 of whom said they would likely do so.&#160;</p><p>Respondents were asked about who they intended to vote for in November as well as a number of other questions. Respondents were asked to provide their zip code, which was later matched to census data regarding population density. Suburbs were classified as any zip code with a population between 100 and 2,900 people per square kilometer.</p><p>Among the survey respondents, suburban women made up 44% of likely voters. As a whole, respondents from zip codes classified as the suburbs make up 80% of likely voters.</p><p>While Trump trails among women in the suburbs, it appears that his campaign understands the importance of their vote. Earlier this month, he made a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-addresses-voter-group-struggled-to-reach-suburban-women-2020-10\">plea to female voters</a> at a rally in Johnstown, Pennsylvania, saying \"Suburban women, will you please like me? Please. Please. I saved your damn neighborhood, OK?\"</p><p>And then in Lansing, Michigan, he further attempted to woo female voters by saying, \"We're getting your husbands back to work.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/election/2016/results/exit-polls\">Exit polls in 2016</a> found that Trump beat former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in suburban areas by 4 percentage points.</p><p>Trump narrowly won some swing states in 2016 by less than 1 percentage point. If Biden can win over the suburbs on Election Day, it may be enough to propel those states back to the Democratic Party.&#160;</p><p>Additionally, Insider polling found that while female suburban voters prefer Biden at higher rates than Trump, rural men are slightly more likely to support Biden than rural women.&#160;</p><section data-track-content=\"\" data-post-type=\"post\"><p><em>SurveyMonkey Audience polls from a national sample balanced by census data of age and gender. Respondents are incentivized to complete surveys through charitable contributions. Generally speaking, digital polling tends to skew toward people with access to the internet. SurveyMonkey Audience doesn't try to weight its sample based on race or income. Polling data collected 1,150 respondents August 7,&#160; 1,106 respondents on August 11, 1,128 respondents August 21-22, 1,073 respondents August 29, 1,161 respondents September 4, 1,107 respondents September 15, 1,017 respondents September 18, 1,122 respondents September 28, 1,176 respondents October 5, and 1,130 respondents on October 12. All polls carried approximately a 3 percentage point margin of error individually.</em></p></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Kelly/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>US stocks sold off on Friday after mega-cap tech earnings results didn't satisfy investor demand for future growth.</strong></li><li><strong>Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, and Facebook reported quarterly earnings on Thursday that mostly beat estimates, but tepid and uncertain growth outlooks sent technology stocks tumbling.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>On top of that, the US hit an all-time high in daily COVID-19 cases on Thursday, reporting about 90,000 new cases.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/indices\">Watch major indexes update live here</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>US stocks finished the day lower on Friday as investors digested quarterly earnings reports from the mega-cap tech companies <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/fb-stock\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/googl-stock\">Alphabet</a>, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amzn-stock\">Amazon</a>, and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aapl-stock\">Apple</a>.</p><p>While all four tech companies beat earnings estimates, tepid and uncertain growth outlooks sent Amazon, Apple, and Facebook down considerably. Only Alphabet traded higher on Friday.&#160;</p><p>On top of that, COVID-19 is still top of mind for investors — the US hit an all-time high in daily cases on Thursday, reporting about 90,000 new cases, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html\">according to The New York Times</a>.</p><p>The S&#38;P 500 slipped 5.6%, while the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 6.5% over the five-day period. Both marked the indexes' worst weekly declines since the height of the pandemic in March.</p><p><strong>Here's where US indexes stood at the 4 p.m. ET close on Friday:</strong></p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestmp;utm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">S&#38;P 500</a>:</strong> 3,269.96, down 1.2%</li><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dow_jones?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingesttm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dow Jones industrial average</a>:</strong> 26,501.60, down 0.6% (158 points)</li><li><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/nasdaq_composite?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingesttm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nasdaq composite</a>:</strong> 10,911.59, down 2.5%</li></ul><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/house-flipping-real-estate-investing-steven-pesavento-shares-strategy-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Steven Pesavento quit his 9-to-5 career to pursue real-estate investing full time. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/facebook-stock-price-q3-earnings-us-users-revenue-sales-covid-2020-10-1029747116\">sold off as much as 7%</a> after its earnings report revealed a decline in US users.</p><p>Here's what Wall Street analysts had to say about <a reports.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-strategy-5-trade-ideas-for-2020-election-morgan-stanley-2020-10\" target=\"_blank\" named its new CFO: Delta Air Lines veteran Paul Jacobson.</p><p>Jacobson starts December 1, the automaker said, and takes over for John Stapleton, who will return to his regular role as CFO of GM's North American business.&#160;</p><p>Stapleton stepped in when former CFO Dhivya Suryadevara moved on to take the same role at fintech firm Stripe in August.</p><p>Jacobson, 48, has been the CFO of Delta since 2012.</p><p>\"Paul is a great addition to the GM senior leadership team and is dedicated to leading the company for the benefit of all stakeholders — customers, employees, suppliers, communities and shareholders,\" GM CEO Mary Barra said in a statement.</p><p>\"We share a commitment to teamwork and inclusion as we work toward our vision of a future with zero crashes, zero emissions, and zero congestion while delivering a best-in-class customer experience, operational and financial excellence, and disciplined capital allocation.\"</p><p>According to Jacobson, \"GM's vision is compelling because it embraces the needs of society, customers and investors, and they are executing an historic technology shift to electrification from a position of strength.\"</p><p>GM plans to launch 22 new electrified vehicles by 2023 and is expected to report strong third-quarter earnings next week as the auto industry recovers from the production shutdowns and sales declines resulting from the coronavirus pandemic.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a concerns","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-trump-november-12-ban-judge-blocks-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2469644e52b729a902ba54?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump tiktok\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tolga Akmen/AFP/Getty Images; Clancy Morgan/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A federal judge blocked President Donald Trump's nationwide ban on the video sharing app TikTok, saying that the administration's phrasing for the national security concerns the app posed was \"hypothetical.\"</li>\n<li>The ban, which Trump originally issued in August, was intended to go into effect on November 12.</li>\n<li>The judge's block of the ban is the latest development in the Trump administration's mission to ban TikTok from the US market over national security concerns.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A federal judge just blocked President Trump's nationwide TikTok ban, saying that his national security concerns were \"hypothetical.\"</p><p>The injunction was filed on Friday in a Pennsylvania district court. It blocks Trump's ban, which was originally issued in August, from going into effect on November 12.</p><p>The injunction is part of a lawsuit that <a href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/theyre-here-to-stay-tiktok-influencers-reassured-so-far-about-platforms-efforts-to-avert-ban\">was filed in mid-September</a> by some TikTok creators who argued that a ban would majorly affect their business and limit their audience growth, as well as restrict their freedom of expression on the platform.</p><p>In a statement to Business Insider, a TikTok spokesperson said \"we are deeply moved by the outpouring of support from our creators, who have worked to protect their rights to expression, their careers, and to help small businesses, particularly during the pandemic. We stand behind our community as they share their voices, and we are committed to continuing to provide a home for them to do so.\"</p><p>The judge's motion to block the ban is the latest development in a series of efforts made by the Trump administration to bar the app from the US market. US officials have criticized the app's China-based parent company, ByteDance, over national security concerns. Some US lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have expressed fear that the Chinese government could access millions of Americans' personal data through the app.</p><p>In addition to the ban, Presiden Trump has also ordered ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, to sell TikTok's US business to an American firm. Microsoft was initially floated as the reported frontrunner for such a deal until Oracle unexpectedly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-oracle-confirms-proposal-submitted-us-government-trusted-technology-partner-2020-9\">won the bid</a> to be the app's \"trusted technology provider.\" However, the Oracle sale remains in limbo, and TikTok's future in the US remains murky.</p><p>As the Trump administration has attempted to block TikTok from the US market,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-ban-competitors-capitalizing-instagram-reels-youtube-byte-dubsmash-2020-7\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"c02bb945132a3254b20aa4335e5b48c4\">other tech firms have moved in with TikTok-like services</a>, like&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/instagram-reels-tiktok-competitor-short-video-us-launch-explainer-2020-7\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"ce30c7f9cd686d1491a3835b11705a24\">Instagram's Reels</a> feature that allows users to create short videos on the platforms. TikTok's rival, the video-sharing app Triller, has also risen to popularity during TikTok's debacle with the Trump administration. ByteDance and TikTok recently <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-bytedance-suing-triller-lawsuit-2020-10\">sued Triller over patent infringement claims</a>, alleging that the companies have been using its technology for years.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-trump-november-12-ban-judge-blocks-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/A70pfn2QLR8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Oct 2020 22:01:18 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f2469644e52b729a902ba54?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"dfa85a8efa527e028ccf87ff216953f2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn11@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-07-478_3bba5eef5e811d4d.webp","destWidth":2000,"destHeight":1500,"sourceBytes":99830,"destBytes":99830,"author":"insider@insider.com (Katie Canales)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f2469644e52b729a902ba54?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn11@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-07-478_3bba5eef5e811d4d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-995_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A70pfn2QLR8:7NZZNY3iWrk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn40@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-28-080_a94f81d41f2edc8d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A70pfn2QLR8:7NZZNY3iWrk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn48@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-30-457_cbcb3db01eaabee9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-32-089_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=A70pfn2QLR8:7NZZNY3iWrk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-29-544_f0b576ebd6755d33.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/A70pfn2QLR8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn92@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-33-718_48ff7ed818e02bac.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167072},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"SCOTT GALLOWAY: Republican senators attacked the wrong enemy at this week's hearing — Twitter and Facebook are actually the GOP's biggest allies","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-galloway-on-why-twitter-facebook-are-gops-greatest-allies-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c616b6f5b3100117248c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jack dorsey senate testimony\" height=\"2724\" width=\"3633\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey answered questions from senators during a hearing focused on Section 230 on Wednesday, Oct. 28.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Scott Galloway is a bestselling author and professor of marketing at NYU Stern.</li>\n<li>The following is his recent blog post and video, republished with permission. It originally ran on his blog, \"<a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"b7607304edf402bcb8ea325f54bfd4f3\">No Mercy / No Malice.\"</a></li>\n<li>Galloway writes that he considers Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey to be among the GOP's&#160;biggest supporters, due to their failure to crack down on misinformation spread using Facebook and Twitter.</li>\n<li>\"The whole thing was a waste, and depressing. A squandered opportunity,\" he says of the Senate's recent <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-twitter-google-senate-republicans-section-230-hearing-2020-10\">hearing</a> where the two tech CEOs were subpoenaed.</li>\n</ul>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>I grew up in LA, so I've been to Disneyland a lot. My first lessons in economics and marketing — scarcity, fiat currency, opportunity cost, sub-brands — were in Anaheim.</p><p>Between 1959 and 1982, park visitors were asked to engage in game-theory and segmentation exercises to get the most magic from their kingdom. In 1972, admission only set you back <a href=\"https://allears.net/walt-disney-world/wdw-planning/wdw-ticket-increase-guide/\">$3.75</a>. It's now $154, an inflation-adjusted increase in excess of 300% (#worthit). Ticket books were extra and segmented A-E (worst to best rides). <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E_ticket\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">E-tickets</a>, needed for the best rides, were a luxury brand positioned between Van Cleef &#38; Arpels and Aman Resorts in the mind of an eight-year-old. They cost 85 cents.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c5a0f6f5b310011724881?format=jpeg\" alt=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/ Scott Galloway\" height=\"1501\" width=\"2667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>I can't stand it when people don't know how to spend their money. I have successful friends in Florida who have a statue of themselves at the base of their circular stairway. Make. It. Stop. Anyway, I felt similar disgust when a rookie visitor would burn an E-ticket on a lesser ride like The Sailing Ship Columbia or The Enchanted Tiki Room. What a waste. You didn't want to go on Space Mountain? Yeah, that makes sense.</p><p>On Wednesday, the Senate commerce committee had a book of E-tickets. They patched in three big tech CEOs (Pichai, Dorsey, and Zuckerberg) and were set to delve into the future of internet regulation. Specifically the thorny but critical topic of Section 230, an all-day pass that lets big tech do whatever they want in the park. They can even smoke pot on the Skyway gondola, a sublime if inefficient way to get from Tomorrowland to Fantasyland, without risking incarceration at Disney Jail. An actual thing. Not that it happened to me in 1983. Definitely not. But I digress.</p><p>Senators on the committee had Space Mountain within reach but opted for Great Moments with Mr. Lincoln instead. Only Ted Cruz was Lincoln. And the Great Moments were weak and weird diversions to The Rainbow Ridge Pack Mules and Tom Sawyer River Rafts. Note: If you're thinking I've taken this analogy way too far, trust your instincts.</p><p>At some point, Senate and House subcommittees will run out of E tickets, and big tech CEOs — whose lobbyists, money, and comms departments have nearly overrun government — will begin ignoring House and Senate subpoenas and will start sending underlings, as they've been to the park too many times and have companies to run.</p><p><em>\"Mr. Dorsey, who the hell elected you and put you in charge of what the media are allowed to report and what the American people are allowed to hear? And why do you persist in behaving as a Democratic super PAC suppressing views contrary to your political beliefs?\" — Senator Ted Cruz</em></p><p>Uh, well, Senator… nobody elects a CEO of a company. They are appointed by a board, who are (theoretically) elected by shareholders. And every media company, including Twitter, despite what they claim, gets to make these decisions.&#160;</p><p>What's crazytown here is the GOP panel members, similar to George W. Bush, decided to attack the wrong enemy (Saddam had as much to do with 9/11 as Bambi's mom, and we'd be better off if both were still alive, can't wait for the hate mail on that one). GOP panel members attacked GOP allies — Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey. Misinformation and conspiracy theories spread 6x faster than truth on their platforms. The far right is more \"gifted\" with both these things than the far left.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/japan-tech-software-us-china-catch-up-startups-investors-2020-10\">How Japan, the home of Sony and Nintendo, fell behind Silicon Valley on software — and how founders and investors plan to catch up</a></em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c5a486f5b310011724884?format=jpeg\" alt=\"https//www.profgalloway.com/ Scott Galloway\" height=\"1085\" width=\"1303\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c5a6469331a0011bc66b2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/ Scott Galloway\" height=\"995\" width=\"1303\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The largest&#160;<em>donors</em>&#160;to the GOP have been Sheldon Adelson and Koch Industries. But the biggest&#160;<em>supporters</em>&#160;of the GOP have been Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey. Both men deftly deploy various lipsticks to distract from the cancer — nose rings, ice baths, silent retreats, and Sheryl Sandberg. The cancer is algorithms that register, in a millionth of a second, that Messrs. Zuckerberg, Pichai, and Dorsey's wealth increases if more enraging/false content is promoted, leading to more engagement, ads, revenue, and shareholder value. The algorithms have been programmed to make these men wealthier, at the expense of our commonwealth.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/quibi-jeffrey-katzenberg-meg-whitman-failure-misunderstood-what-people-want-2020-10\">Quibi's biggest mistake was not knowing who its audience was — if it hadn't tried to beat TikTok and YouTube it might have stood a chance</a></em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c5a7b6f5b310011724886?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"813\" width=\"1304\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>Master Class</strong></h2><p>This summer, the House antitrust subcommittee, chaired by Representative Cicilline, put on a master class on how to hold a hearing. They were prepared, disciplined and went straight for the Pirates of the Caribbean — allocated resources effectively. I wonder if the House is becoming the body where youth, preparation, greater turnover, and diversity (on several dimensions) elevates their brand above what was once considered the chamber with more gravitas. The Senate's \"hearing\" this week was a sh-tshow, with Senators Cruz and Blackburn swinging wildly and not landing a glove on the platforms. It was similar to watching our <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Eagle_Claw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">failed attempt</a> to end the Iran hostage crisis… minus the dignity and heroism. This was an October surprise that didn't even try to cover up how politically motivated the timing and flawed the mission.&#160;</p><p>The silver lining? A split screen of Jack Dorsey and Ted Cruz likely means beards have jumped the shark. Overdue.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c5aa469331a0011bc66b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"563\" width=\"1303\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The whole thing was a waste, and depressing. A squandered opportunity, similar to venturing to \"The Happiest Place on Earth\" to eat Meat Lovers' Flatbread at Pinocchio's Village Haus (both exist) and ride Walt Disney's Carousel of Progress, where we are forced to watch creepy animatronic figures discuss technology through the lens of the 50s.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-galloway-on-why-twitter-facebook-are-gops-greatest-allies-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-32-059_e5203eabc3e8d535.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167090},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"Netflix just hiked up their prices — here's how much every subscription plan costs now","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-is-netflix","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c88816f5b310011724a26?format=jpeg\" alt=\"netflix logo figures\" height=\"1498\" width=\"2996\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>How much Netflix costs will depend on which plan you choose.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong>Netflix offers three streaming plans, and two DVD and Blu-ray plans, each of which has a different price.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Netflix's streaming plans cost $8.99 per month for the Basic plan, $13.99 per month for the Standard, and $17.99 per month for the Premium.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>The Standard DVD and Blu-ray plan starts at $7.99 per month, and the Premier plan starts at $11.99 per month.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Depending on the Netflix plan you choose, you'll have access to Ultra HD video, and the ability to stream on multiple screens at once.</strong></li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>Whether you use <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/netflix\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Netflix</a> in addition to cable television or as a replacement, most people would agree that it's become nearly essential. With a vast library of TV shows, movies, and Netflix original programming, Netflix has become a cultural juggernaut of the 21st century.</p><p>Like its competitors, Netflix offers a variety of subscription tiers, which differ on price and features. In the US, Netflix even still offers the ability to order DVD and Blu-ray discs in the mail.</p><p>Here's a guide to what Netflix charges for each of its plans.</p><h2><strong>How much Netflix's streaming plans cost</strong></h2><p>Netflix offers three streaming plans: Basic, Standard, and Premium, starting at $9 per month and ending at $18 per month. Here's what you get with each plan.</p><ul><li><strong>Basic</strong>. The Basic streaming plan costs $8.99 per month and has the most limited features. You can only use it on a single screen at a time (which is fine if you're the only user of the account), and resolution is limited to standard definition (SD), which is equivalent to old, pre-HD television.</li><li><strong>Standard</strong>. The Standard streaming plan costs $13.99 per month and allows you two watch on two screens at a time in high definition (HD).</li><li><strong>Premium</strong>. The Premium streaming plan costs $17.99 per month. For that, you can watch on four screens at once (ideal for a large family), and you can video programming in HD or 4K Ultra HD, if available.</li></ul><h2><strong>How much Netflix's DVD and Blu-ray plans costs</strong></h2><p>In the US, Netflix continues to offer discs by mail at <a href=\"https://dvd.netflix.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dvd.netflix.com</a>. This was, in fact, the way Netflix originally delivered its content — via DVD — when it launched in 1998. It added streaming video in 2007, and DVD rentals declined rapidly. Today, it's still an option, though an uncommon one.</p><p>Here are the pricing plans.</p><ul><li><strong>Standard</strong>. The Standard DVD plan costs $7.99 per month. If you prefer Blu-ray, the cost is $9.99 per month. &#160;In both cases, Netflix allows you to keep one disc at a time for as long as you want (as soon as you return that disc, Netflix immediately sends you the next disc listed in your queue). There's no limit to how many discs you can watch over time, though — the only limitation is how quickly you can watch and return discs.</li><li><strong>Premier</strong>. The Premier DVD plan allows you to keep two discs at a time for $11.99 per month, or $14.99 per month for Blu-rays. Otherwise, the plan works the same as the Standard plan.</li></ul><h2>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-netflix-gift-card\" data-analytics-position=\"8\" data-analytics-module=\"\">How to use a Netflix gift card to pay for your Netflix subscription plan</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/does-apple-tv-have-netflix\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"e9f35cab23ba579ab6a4f5258fbfb80e\">'Does Apple TV have Netflix?': How to download Netflix on your Apple TV from the App Store</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-netflix-profile-on-roku\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"16cc3b9711810358dd6974d4a2fb245c\">How to change your Netflix profile on a Roku player in 2 ways</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-get-netflix-on-ps4\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"d7645f0510a0ab619ad9ac1bcc3a925d\">How to get Netflix on a PS4 to watch TV shows and movies from your console</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-language-on-netflix\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"1094ce04303634dd3f41861c5054f9c5\">How to change the primary language on your Netflix profile, on desktop and mobile</a></h3></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-is-netflix'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/50qGBRsRY-w\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Oct 2020 21:43:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9c887369331a0011bc685a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"f9db9514e78ee813968cb8fbc8344478","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn12@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-27-671_a73134ea25a208bd.webp","destWidth":2454,"destHeight":1841,"sourceBytes":57650,"destBytes":57650,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dave Johnson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9c88816f5b310011724a26?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn39@2020_5/2020/10/31/07-26-33-287_81f71dda36ce46c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-995_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn83@2020_5/2020/10/31/07-26-35-954_46231989fb98dd2c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn35@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-34-071_092f22ca4e833bab.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-32-089_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=50qGBRsRY-w:Oat_-qrUYJw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn89@2020_5/2020/10/31/07-26-36-672_0da6e6e78b758063.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/50qGBRsRY-w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn43@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-27-031_d79342e189f8ea08.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167103},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"How billionaires saw their net worth increase by half a trillion dollars during the pandemic","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/billionaires-net-worth-increases-coronavirus-pandemic-2020-7","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/oebMIVL6-jZbcmOYf.html\"\nwidth=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"auto\" title=\"How billionaires saw their net worth increase by half a trillion dollars during the pandemic\"\nstyle=\"position:absolute;\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>40 million Americans filed for <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/coronavirus\">unemployment during the pandemic</a>, but <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/billionaires-profited-average-of-42-billion-weekly-during-pandemic-2020-7\">billionaires saw their net worth increase</a> by half a trillion dollars.</li>\n<li>This isn't the first time billionaires have seen gains while others dealt with loss, and it tends to tie back to two things. First, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-representatives-blast-large-companies-small-business-coronavirus-loans-2020-5\">government disproportionately gives more aid to larger companies.</a></li>\n<li>Then, when the stock market bounces back, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/congress-repeating-critical-mistake-2008-financial-crisis-inequality-2020-5\">unequal bailouts</a> mean that the wealthy still have money on hand to invest and thus profit, while the middle and lower classes do not.</li>\n<li>Wealth-friendly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-microsoft-avoids-taxes-loopholes-irs-2013-1\">tax laws and loopholes</a>then keep those billionaires at the top. Knowing all of this, some are advocating for policies to help level the playing field and create change.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> This is the unemployment rate during the COVID-19 pandemic. And this is Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos' net worth during that same time span. From March to June 2020, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos saw his wealth rise by an estimated $48 billion. The founder of the video-conferencing platform Zoom grew his nest egg by over $2.5 billion, and former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer's net worth increased by $15.7 billion.</p><p>These kinds of examples might lead you to think that when billionaires profit during a crisis, it's just a matter of right place, right time. Well, that's not false, but it's not entirely true either. Casino magnate Sheldon Adelson saw his wealth increase by $5 billion, while Elon Musk saw an increase of $17.2 billion. When you add up the numbers, billionaires in the United States have increased their total net worth $637 billion during the COVID-19 pandemic so far.</p><p>At the same time, more than 40 million Americans filed for unemployment. With tens of millions of Americans out of a paycheck and the stock market plummeting by 37% in March, how is it that the rich have continued getting richer?</p><p>This isn't the first time billionaires have seen gains while a large portion of Americans were feeling losses. When the housing bubble burst in 2007, home prices fell 21% and roughly 3.1 million homes were foreclosed on in the United States. The stock market plummeted by over 50%. And by the end of 2009, 8.8 million Americans had lost their jobs. And the effects lingered. From 2009 to 2012, the incomes of the bottom 99% grew by only 0.4%, but the income of the top 1% grew by a staggering 31.4% in the same time span. And it all ties back to two things.</p><p>First, the government disproportionately gave more aid to banks and corporations. In 2008, the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act was signed into law, creating a $700 billion program to purchase devalued assets from banks. This was called the Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP. Later, President Obama would direct $75 billion in funds from TARP to help reduce interest payments for homeowners. That means homeowners received around 10% of the direct relief that banks and corporations did.</p><p>And this leads to reason No. 2. When the stock market bounced back, the unequal bailouts meant that the wealthy still had money on hand to invest and thus profit, while the middle and lower classes did not. In 2008, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates to near zero. They would remain that low for nearly a decade. This paved the way for a historic bull market on Wall Street that began in 2009 and lasted until March 2020, when the pandemic hit.</p><p>In that time, the S&#38;P 500 gained 462%. That means that a $1,000 investment in the S&#38;P 500 at the low point of the financial crisis could have returned roughly $4,620, while someone who could afford a $1 million investment could have pulled in over $4.6 million.</p><p>By 2009, the world's high-net-worth individuals had grown their share of global wealth by 19% to $39 trillion, recouping nearly all of their losses in a single year. That quick recovery and larger share of the world's wealth enabled them to continue to make money at an exponential rate. In fact, the top 1% captured 95% of the income gains made from 2009 to 2012. And by 2020, the combined wealth of the billionaire class in the United States had increased by over 80%.</p><p>Which brings us back to the moment when the coronavirus pandemic rocked the economy. In 2019, the Fed reported that four in 10 Americans didn't have enough cash in their bank accounts to cover a $400 unexpected expense. And in the first few months of 2020, 40 million Americans found themselves unemployed due to COVID-19. Many small businesses had to close due to lockdowns and social distancing, while others were forced to try to operate with entirely remote staff.</p><p>The Small Business Administration made $349 billion available to small businesses with the Paycheck Protection Program. But like in 2008, $243 million of that was snapped up by large, publicly traded corporations, some of which were valued at over $100 million. Even hedge funds submitted claims to try to tap into what they saw as free money.</p><p>On March 16, 2020, just five days after COVID-19 was declared a pandemic, the Dow suffered the worst single-day points drop in its history. But by June 4, seven of the world's richest people had seen their fortunes increase by over 50%. Part of what made this possible was a stock-market rebound fueled both by the Paycheck Protection Program and actions by the Fed. Again, the Fed lowered short-term interest rates for banks to near 0%, and as before, they have promised to hold those rates low until the economy is on track.</p><p>This is a cycle that has happened time and time again. During the earthquake in Haiti in 2010, only 2.5% of the $195 million of relief funds went to Haitian companies. Much of the rest was awarded to DC-based construction companies. And when Hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans in 2005, real-estate developer Joseph Canizaro said the clearing out caused by Katrina represented some \"very big opportunities.\" Canizaro was selected as part of a panel to develop the Bring New Orleans Back plan, part of which put a stop on reconstruction of low-income neighborhoods until the residents returned. Of course, residents couldn't return to their destroyed homes, and many were foreclosed on, paving the way for others to buy those properties and develop them.</p><p>When the time did come to rebuild New Orleans, the engineering and construction company KBR received no-bid contracts from the federal government for tens of millions of dollars. KBR received $31 billion in contracts from the government between 2001 and 2010. Vice President Dick Cheney served as CEO of KBR's parent company, Halliburton, for the five years leading up to his two terms in office.</p><p>Combined with their immense investing and purchasing power, billionaires have had government resources in addition to their own resources to profit from during economic upheavals. And wealth-friendly tax laws and loopholes then keep those billionaires at the top. Legal structures such as limited liability companies protect personal assets from being repossessed to pay the debts from business downturns. As it's set up today, IRS rules allowed Amazon to pay $0 in taxes two years in a row. When its bill finally came due in 2019, it paid just $162 million, a measly 1.2% of the company's income that year.</p><p>And it's not just Amazon. Taxes paid by billionaires have decreased 79% since 1980. And those are just the legal avenues that the wealthy take to avoid paying taxes. In 2017, researchers estimated that about 10% of the world's GDP was stashed in offshore tax havens. A study in 2012 found that as much as $32 trillion was being held offshore by the world's wealthiest people.</p><p>So, after reviewing all this, what can be done to help level the playing field? A recent report by the Institute for Policy Studies lays out several action items. It suggests forming a pandemic profiteering oversight committee that would go beyond the oversight of federal stimulus money. It also supports the Corporate Transparency Act, which would create stronger regulations to prevent US billionaires from using shell corporations to hide their income. After the House passed the bill in 2019, it was introduced in the Senate but has not been brought to a vote.</p><p>Other suggestions include an emergency 10% millionaire income surtax, a stimulus package aimed at funding charities, instituting a wealth tax, and reducing the amount allowed by the gift and estate tax. Last, and perhaps most importantly, the report underscores the need to shut down the global hidden-wealth economy. The US alone is estimated to lose nearly $200 billion in tax revenues to offshore havens each year. That's roughly three times the amount of all the money budgeted for the Department of Education in 2021.</p><p>Changes like the ideas above are global in scale and require political cooperation to become reality. If the relationship between wealth and income inequality are ever going to change, it's going to require all of us.'</p><p><em>EDITOR'S NOTE: This video was originally published in August 2020.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/billionaires-net-worth-increases-coronavirus-pandemic-2020-7'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=ZFoiQBSw5Zs:UP-0u1pUfgU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZFoiQBSw5Zs:UP-0u1pUfgU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZFoiQBSw5Zs\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 30 Oct 2020 21:30:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f22d3bf5fa9a4650320a8f7?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"200b3c572992160855a1cac0a8e44515","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn17@2020_2/2020/10/31/07-26-25-958_b3a72ae8ae3152f8.webp","destWidth":1440,"destHeight":1080,"sourceBytes":47318,"destBytes":47318,"author":"insider@insider.com (Hiatt Woods)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-995_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZFoiQBSw5Zs:UP-0u1pUfgU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn7@2020_5/2020/10/31/07-26-30-841_dd33a64d1d509225.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZFoiQBSw5Zs:UP-0u1pUfgU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn31@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-27-870_4976073310fc8816.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/31/07-26-32-089_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZFoiQBSw5Zs:UP-0u1pUfgU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn44@2020_4/2020/10/31/07-26-37-068_81807457de3ea7db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZFoiQBSw5Zs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn61@2020_6/2020/10/31/07-26-35-829_87555e6872a14ee8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604129167077},{"createdTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","updatedTime":"2020-10-31 15:26:07","title":"Insider poll: Biden voters are more anxious about the economy than Trump voters","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-voters-more-anxious-about-economy-than-trump-voters-poll-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9c56fb6f5b310011724865?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages economy covid\" height=\"723\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>People wearing protective masks walk by a going out of business sign displayed outside Century 21 in New York City.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Noam Galai/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A new series of polls suggests there's a link between a voter's financial status and their preferred 2020 presidential candidate.</li>\n<li>Affluent voters tended to favor President Donald Trump, according to the data.&#160;</li>\n<li>Former Vice President Joe Biden was more likely to gain support from voters with financial hardships.</li>\n<li>The surveys were conducted by Insider with SurveyMonkey from August to October.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A new series of polls suggests that voters who are economically anxious, financially imperiled due to coronavirus, and otherwise worried about money are more likely to back Democratic nominee Joe Biden, not President Donald Trump.</p><p>The surveys, conducted by Insider with SurveyMonkey, reveal that Americans' housing, employment, and debt situations each played roles in their voting habits. Overall, the data indicates that affluent voters tended to favor Trump.</p><p>Biden was more likely to gain support from voters with less financial stability: those out of work due to the pandemic, those who rented, those with fewer assets, those who didn't own businesses, and so on.&#160;</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on economic anxiety\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-dzxY4\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/dzxY4/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"477\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>&#160;</p><p>This breakdown comes from an aggregation of nine polls taken between August 8 and October 12. All told, the polls combined to 10,077 respondents, 8,623 of whom indicated they were registered to vote and 8,321 of whom said they would likely do so. Respondents were asked about their intentions of who they would vote for in November as well as a number of other questions.</p><p>The polls come during the final stretch of the 2020 race, with just four days left until election day. On the campaign trail, Trump continues to position himself as the stronger candidate when it comes to the economy, hoping it will carry him to victory. Meanwhile, Biden has made the economic and personal devastation of the coronavirus pandemic a central part of his campaign, and promised to rebuild the economy if he wins the White House.&#160;</p><p>According to the polls, voters who faced economic setbacks from the public health crisis skewed toward Biden. Similarly, households that have been hit by layoffs in recent years tended to lean toward Biden as well.&#160;</p><ul><li>Renters preferred Biden by 10 percentage points, along with people who live at home with their parents, by 21 percentage points.</li><li>Homeowners, roughly 51 percent of respondents, were more inclined to vote for Trump by 6 percentage points.</li><li>Americans with more than one car were on Trump's side by 13 percentage points. Those who owned an American-made car shifted 32 percentage points more toward Trump.</li></ul><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on car and home ownership\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-k5F0q\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/k5F0q/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"507\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>&#160;</p><ul><li>Business owners also favored Trump by 13 percentage points.&#160;</li></ul><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on business ownership\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-KgCgX\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/KgCgX/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"333\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>&#160;</p><ul><li>Parents alligned more with Trump, whereas those without children were 21 percentage points likelier to vote for Biden.</li></ul><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on parental status\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-qaFz3\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/qaFz3/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"385\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>&#160;</p><ul><li>Voters with student loans favored Biden by 13 percentage points.&#160;</li><li>Households where a family member had declared bankruptcy before favored toward Trump by 7 percentage points.</li></ul><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Trump-Biden voter shift based on assets and debts\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-MwyHD\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/MwyHD/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"499\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p><em>SurveyMonkey Audience polls from a national sample balanced by census data of age and gender. Respondents are incentivized to complete surveys through charitable contributions. Generally speaking, digital polling tends to skew toward people with access to the internet. SurveyMonkey Audience doesn't try to weight its sample based on race or income. Polling data collected 1,150 respondents August 7,&#160; 1,106 respondents on August 11, 1,128 respondents August 21-22, 1,073 respondents August 29, 1,161 respondents September 4, 1,107 respondents September 15, 1,017 respondents September 18, 1,122 respondents September 28, 1,176 respondents October 5, and 1,130 respondents on October 12. All polls carried approximately a 3 percentage point margin of error individually.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-voters-more-anxious-about-economy-than-trump-voters-poll-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gm4aOQKmPM4:JWfcRIchbbU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=gm4aOQKmPM4:JWfcRIchbbU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gm4aOQKmPM4:JWfcRIchbbU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"
